poem:
### Wrong Number Inspiration

A ringing in the night—  
wrong number, a voice  
seeking the Pinkerton,  
but finds instead  
a poet bound  
to spiral thoughts, unraveling  
whispers of city shadows  
threading through dreams,  
where mysteries open  
like windows,  
caught in the weave  
of mistaken calls, marking  
paths to be read, again  
and again  
in the hush of paper.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Paul Auster’s The New York Trilogy review – a classic that will be read for decades to come It was a wrong number that started it – literally in the case of The New York Trilogy. In 1980, or thereabouts, Paul Auster twice answered the phone, only to hear a voice ask: “Is this the Pinkerton Agency?” (Pinkerton is a legendary American detective bureau.) He told the caller they had a wrong number, yet he". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
